CommentsDate: 评论于 2022年9月6日 在美国 🇺🇸 发布
CommentsContent: This unit came highly recommended by various internet review sites, but my experience with it has been frustrating.  The thermastat seems to measure the temperature of the outside air rather than the inside air.  Our bedroom often stays warm even as the outside cools down, so the unit will often be off as the temperature inside goes several degrees past the setpoint.  There is an app for this unit, which will conveniently tell you the temperature the unit is sensing.  I have an indoor thermometer and these two temperatures are often very different.  There is a feature that allows you to control off of the temperature at the remote instead of the unit, but this feature only works as long as the remote stays connected to the unit, which it will not do for more than 10 minutes rendering that feature useless.  The result is we have to control the unit semi-manually by either raising or lowering the setpoint to extremes.  Incidentally, we have similar unit from a different manufacturer (identical chassis - probably the same hardware with different circuit board) and it has the same issue.  It also has a high pitched squeal when it starts the compressor up, so if it does kick on and off at night while you sleep, hope you're a deep sleeper.

CommentsTitle: My all time favorite air conditioner.
CommentsDate: 评论于 2022年9月6日 在美国 🇺🇸 发布
CommentsContent: I love this ac. It is easily the best I have owned. Being able to remotely turn the ac on and off is great. It also cools down quickly, our room was 83 and within 30 minutes it had the temp down to 63. It is 112 today and the ac is easily keeping the room at 70. It also notifies you when the filter needs cleaned or it needs to be drained. And you can turn off the button noises and lights. The negatives are it is kind of noisy. Unlike other ac's it does not keep the fan running the fan only comes on when the compressor is running. So when the fan engages it is often at full speed and it is a bit loud all of the sudden and sometimes it makes this beeping activation type noise that reminds me of r2d2. Since the remote contains the temperature sensor, so you have to think about where you place it. No matter where I place it, it doesn't match the Alexa air quality temperature sensor and sometimes I have to turn it off and back on again to get it to run when the room is hotter than it reports. But even having said all that I would buy this unit again. And plan on doing so when my other ac dies.

CommentsDate: 评论于 2022年9月3日 在美国 🇺🇸 发布
CommentsContent: This air conditioner rumbles like a jet plane taking off every time it kicks on. We even put a board under it to see if it helps. You can get used to that though, what I hate the most though is the way the filter is designed. It’s not easy to clean, there are a billion little plastic pieces creating little jails for dirt to collect in. You have to take it off and use a toothbrush as a little broom to clean each lil jail cell. Then as if this wasn’t enough of a pain, you have the swap that collects in the bottom of this thing. I can’t even figure out why or how it’s collecting water when I don’t use the dehumidifier portion. Regardless, every other day, a new swap has formed in the bottom. I was ready to accept this lil droids flaws of it could quell the infernal hell that was my room, but alas, it could not. Hell is roughly 200 sq ft with 2 doors to minimize some of that area and this lil droid, set at 63 degrees, can’t even manage to keep it a solid 68 degrees. Don’t waste your money on this. It my humble opinion, this is not the droid you are looking for.

CommentsTitle: Be careful following the manufacturer's instructions
CommentsDate: 评论于 2022年8月31日 在美国 🇺🇸 发布
CommentsContent: The product itself works well enough, but the instructions and support are terrible. The instructions tell you to attach the adhesive foam to your window frame, and like an idiot, I followed the instructions. This makes the "portable" AC no longer portable since it now has to be in that one place, and you won't be able to move it to another place without buying additional adhesive foam, which the manufacturer will not supply.Instead what I should have done was to attach the adhesive foam to the slider itself so that it can be moved around or put away without putting a punch of sticky gunk on my window frame.I contacted Midea's customer support and they blamed me for following their instructions (which they also included in the video on the Amazon page), and wanted to charge me for an entire installation kit even though all I needed was replacement adhesive foam.

CommentsTitle: Good option if window unit is impractical
CommentsDate: 评论于 2022年8月28日 在美国 🇺🇸 发布
CommentsContent: This is the best portable AC I've found/used. My previous portable AC with the same ASHRAE BTU rating could only keep my room 10 degrees cooler than outdoors, which was unacceptable since we had 3 solid months of >100F weather this year. This unit can keep my room at least 18F degrees cooler than outdoors. I think the dual-hose design really helps. I think to get any better cooling performance you would have to get a window AC unit, which could get you ~3000 more BTU on a normal 15-amp, 120v outlet.This AC is also much quieter than my previous portable. Not as quiet as a newer, quality window unit, but close to it on the lowest setting. I think this unit uses a variable speed compressor motor, making it quieter and more efficient than ACs without.I do not like the remote control. It's very large. It has an LCD display that is supposed to show things like the mode and temperature set-point, but it will sometimes get of of sync with the AC unit (if you use the controls on the unit itself, or the AC unit didn't receive the IR signal from the remote).I haven't tried the heating function out yet, so can't comment on that. I plan on using it this winter, so I hope it works well.In conclusion, if a window AC is impractical for whatever reason (window location/type not suitable), this is a solid choice.

CommentsContent: Bought an equivalent HiSense unit that sounded like a jet taking off and failed to cool my 500sqft space. This thing is super quiet, cools the space with ease, and readily integrated with Alexa. My only gripe is Alexa can't set the fan speed back to auto. Setup was simple, and the unit came with adhesive insulation for the window, window insert, and an insulated sleeve for the hose further boosting efficiency. My monthly AC cost dropped by about 20% or more compared to the other unit.UPDATE: Discovered today the heat function shuts off below 41 F to protect the coil from frost. Where I live fall sees nighttime temperatures dip below freezing often and it's unacceptable to have the heater shut off when its needed most. I'm trying to delay firing up my boiler with oil costs. This product is falling well short of my expectations for its heating function. Proper air source heat pumps briefly turn on the AC to thaw the coil then switch back to heat. They don't let their customers freeze.

CommentsTitle: Still pulls in outside air, contrary to the marketing
CommentsDate: 评论于 2022年8月25日 在美国 🇺🇸 发布
CommentsContent: This unit does indeed pull in outdoor air. Even with the unit off, if you put your hand near the vents beneath where the hose connects to the unit, you'll feel a strong amount of airflow. Heck, you'll feel it strongly around all the drain ports - even all along the base of the unit! I was having quite a bit of trouble figuring out why this was having so much trouble with lowering the relative humidity below 60% - now I figured it out. I don't live in a particularly humid climate. If you're thinking of using this to keep your bedroom below 68 degrees while sleeping, then best of luck - it certainly will accomplish this, but it will absolutely struggle to reduce the RH below 60%. It regularly hovers at 65% throughout the night according to both of my sensors, even with my central AC kicking in every so often for ventilation. Tried running it on dry mode with the hose draining outside, and it still can't keep up. You do not want your indoor relative humidity level to reach above 60% as it introduces a whole host of issues, both to you health and your home. Was also wondering why my allergies were flaring up. I also live adjacent to a busy street, and I ultimately prefer to not have a continuous airflow of car exhaust into my home. Had I known this, I wouldn't have purchased this unit. I just do not understand why Midea makes such an outrageously incorrect claim. Now, I have to go through the hassle of returning this unit - already had to fabricate a custom mount to fit my sliding door that took a lot of time and effort to effectively weather seal before I figured this out, so yeah, I've wasted a monumental amount of time trying to find an adequate cooling solution. Unfortunately, this isn't it. Midea, please change your marketing and make it clear that this does, in fact, introduce outdoor air whilst the unit is running and while it is off/not runningOh, and I just remembered that I've been having a moth problem - I was thinking at first that it was the from the unit since I was finding them underneath and around it, but how could that be? The hose system is sealed after all... Hahaha, no it's not. So you are also taking a chance on allowing insects in. Great!I spent an unhealthy amount of time researching portable ACs before getting this. Thought it was going to be perfect, but alas, it has a glaring problem that's a result of lazy engineering. And this issue extends beyond merely introducing outdoor air - because the air appears to infiltrate throughout the internals, this is absolutely going to shorten the lifespan of it. There is no way you're going to be able to effectively clean it. And once you look in the hoses after running it for just a week, you'll find it's absolutely filthy. You can extrapolate that the inside must be in a similar condition since the airpath is not isolated in any sense; it is just marketing garbage.Wish I had spent all of this time just installing a mini split - lots of ones that are DIY and come pre-charged are around the price of this. I suppose that's really the only way to ensure that you're not circulating outdoor air.
PurchasemModel_Size: 颜色: 黑色//白色尺寸: 14,000 BTU with Heat
PurchasemModel_Color: 颜色: 黑色//白色尺寸: 14,000 BTU with Heat

CommentsDate: 评论于 2022年8月25日 在美国 🇺🇸 发布
CommentsContent: If you live anywhere with high humidity this is not the AC for you. Because it pulls in air from outside the process of cooling it dehumidifies the air. Where I live this fills the half liter drain pan in about 30 minutes where I live. I also found out that the pump used in the dehumidify mode does not kick in in cool mode so you need to get the unit high enough off the ground to let gravity do the work. If you don't, once the drain pan is full the unit stops cooling to prevent the drain pan overflowing, however my unit leaked no matter how empty the pan was.I'm sure it's great for dry areas, just be aware in humid ones.

CommentsDate: 评论于 2022年8月20日 在美国 🇺🇸 发布
CommentsContent: Got this unit after reading a positive review on Wirecutter.  Overall, very impressed.PROS:Very quiet.  Sound level is comparable to the "fan only" setting on my other portable AC (Black+Decker 8K BTU) and no jarring compressor start/ stop.Good hose design.  Dual hose stays cooler than single.  In addition, the up-facing outlet is easier to route to window-level, allowing the unit to be closer to the wall (usually the hose comes straight out of the back, so the unit has to sit further into the room)Blows ice cold.  No issues with power or temp, cools well (note that my room is 300 sq feet)Nice mobile app.  You can turn the AC on remotely (say, 10 mins before you arrive) so you can come home to a cool living room.CONS:Some water leakage.  After running it for several super hot, humid days, there was a little puddle next to it (a teaspoon or so).  So you need to drain it after extreme humidity days, though I've had zero water drain out (or leak) since then, even after many days of use.Doesn't (completely) solve the negative pressure issue.  Portable ACs suck air from other parts of your house.  This unit draws less surrounding air than my B+D, but it's not 100%.  I keep a small window crack in my other room to bring in fresh air (but that of course reduces efficiency of the cooling).Black Darth Vader styling.  Like Darth, it dominates the room.  Doesn't look bad, but I would have preferred it in white (like my B+D).Takes up more window real estate.  As much as I love the dual hose, it's big.  It takes a full 10" of window vs. 6" for my 8K BTU Black+Decker.Despite the drawbacks, I'm VERY happy with this unit and I strongly recommend it.

CommentsTitle: Summer nights never felt so cool
CommentsDate: 评论于 2022年8月12日 在美国 🇺🇸 发布
CommentsContent: I sleep hot regardless of the season. My options were to buy a huge fan and place it on me at all times during the night with a sheet as a blanket or just suffer through it. It took my bed being soaked with my sweat several summers in a row for me to give up and look into an air conditioner. I didn't want anything super amazing as the room I sleep in is fairly small. I did want a dual hose design since I've heard they're better at removing water from the system but it wasn't a deal breaker if I didn't get that.After much looking I came upon this unit. It has a remote, it works with Alexa, I can control the unit with my smartphone, it has the dual hose system but most importantly it's energy efficient. You see I used to have a hotel grade air conditioner and it ran most of the time due to the room it was in having no air flow. That unit was a champ as it kept that large room chilly all the time. Though it used a lot of power. It added over a hundred dollars to our power bill every month and I just couldn't deal with that again. Now this unit is much better but it only runs when I sleep and I clean the filter on the regular to keep it from using too much power. It hasn't broke my bank yet so that's always a plus. Oh, and did I mention this unit is a beast at cooling? I know I said the room is small but I'd never expect this unit to cool my bedroom in less than a couple of minutes like this unit does. Most of the time I forget to turn it on via my phone and it doesn't really matter. I enter my room, hit the on button and get into bed and within minutes I'm nice and chilly for a good nights sleep.I have very little to complain about with this air conditioner. It checks off a lot of boxes I had for what I wanted and then some. The only thing I can say is that it's a bit noisy. I don't see that as a bad thing cause most units are loud. Actually I don't know if I could sleep without the noise now. But if you have to have silence in order to drift off to dreamland then maybe find something else. The amount of features this unit has at a fairly decent price accompanied with it being energy efficient should be a top contender for most. Highly recommend.Whoops, almost forgot. My unit was missing the adapter that hooks to the plastic hose so to have water drawn away from the unit and into a better place. I contacted Midea for a replacement part and was told they don't carry certain parts and my only option was to send the entire unit back for a replacement. This was well after I had installed the unit. I, like the adult I am, called them stupid and argued their flawed logic. Sending a heavy piece of tech back because they forgot to add a small and almost weightless piece of plastic was asinine. Why put me and the poor delivery people through something so frustrating over something so simple. That conversation went on for too long and got me nowhere. In the end I didn't need the part but I highly suggest anyone buying this to check every part to make sure it's all there cause from what I can tell they don't carry parts that a normal company would.
PurchasemModel_Size: 颜色: 黑色//白色尺寸: 12,000 BTU
PurchasemModel_Color: 颜色: 黑色//白色尺寸: 12,000 BTU

CommentsTitle: It does cool you down.. but it's loud and has inadequate water reservoir
CommentsDate: 评论于 2022年8月11日 在美国 🇺🇸 发布
CommentsContent: Ok, the unit arrived, boy howdy, it's big and heavy.But, installation is easy, the "snorkel" to route the warm air through a windows is solid/sturdy and adequate. The window slider to fit different size windows was solid and definitely wide enough for nearly every windows. So far so good.Why 4 stars (and I was generous)?Noise:It's noisy! forget "whisper quite"... in A/C mode full blast you can NOT bear to sit next to it. Turn on, run(!) and leave room and come back when coldOr leave it at lowest level, which I do, then it's acceptable, it's in the office next to the desk Even then it starts to wear you down. I do think that you can NOT have this thing sitting in your bedroom and expect to sleep. Sorry.Water/Condensor:I was surprise, it stopped working after 2 h runtime with P1 error. Turns out, that means the condenser-reservoir is full and needs emptying.Well, it's at the very bottom of the unit, you need a very thin tray, saucer(?)to empty it. else you end up lifting the unit. Another 2 hours later: P1 again! Rinse repeat, I mean: empty, repeat.It's only 2 cups, 16 ounces, folks! I measured it. So this beast, this huge portable AC unit has a pint-sized condenser water reservoir. Why, guys, why?I ended up putting it up on an empty wine-box and letting it leak/dribble into a bigger bucket. See photo.

CommentsTitle: Pulls unconditioned outside air inside only cool place is in front of it during the heat of the day
CommentsDate: 评论于 2022年8月11日 在美国 🇺🇸 发布
CommentsContent: Learning to use it took a while. With condenser input drawn from inside the house I am careful to use it only for precooling. I found that my wall furnace flue does'nt provide adequate air flow so I opened the stove vent baffle and provided good flow. That said, now we can feel the breeze, outside temperature is sucked right in. When it is 70 outside it is cool, when it is 108 it is hot! I plan to fabricate a duct system to give the condenser direct outside access so I can reseal our humble abode. I haven't worked in HVAC since 1960, but the basics don't appear to have changed.

CommentsTitle: Read if you have a horizontal sliding window/window much higher than the height of the AC.
CommentsDate: 评论于 2022年8月7日 在美国 🇺🇸 发布
CommentsContent: January 2023 update: I kept the unit, packaging it back up seemed like a monumental task that I just didn’t want to tackle. This a/c, for all its flaws, kept my oven of a bedroom (poorly insulated, super high wood plank cabin style ceilings, all day full sun on three sides, top floor) cool in the summer. Bumping up to four stars for cooling power alone. Probably wildly inefficient, but it got the job done and then some. Going to work with a plastics place to make a custom window attachment for my horizontal slider to alleviate the tab and gap issues mentioned below.Original review:I was torn between this and the LG dual inverter, ended up purchasing this one because of the extra 2,000 doe. I wish I had gotten the LG instead. The unit body seems well made, but the inflexible giant stubby hose and the cheap and ineffective plastic window attachments completely ruin an otherwise decent a/c.1. I have a slider that moves sideways instead of up, so I needed the extra plastic attachment. You’re supposed to join the two halves together and insert a screw to hold them together.  The screw “screws” in, but it doesn’t keep the two pieces together because there seem to be no actual threads inside the hole.2. Because the hose isn’t round, you can’t just screw it into the window kit like a lid on a jar. Once you assemble this flimsy plastic horizontal converter, you attach it by snapping plastic tabs at each corner into the window kit. The V shaped tabs rely on pressure to stay snapped in, but the hose is too heavy and the plastic tabs keep coming unsnapped, leaving a gaping open hole on whatever side they popped off on. With all the popping off and popping back in, top tabs won’t make it long.3. The tabs popping off to leave an open hole is only the start of your outside air woes once you see the entire horizontal attachment has been DESIGNED with air gaps. Midea includes loads of foam to seal your windows, but honestly, why bother sealing anything when the actual window kit itself defeats the purpose?4. The hose is an interesting idea, but absolutely terrible in reality. Wildly inflexible, giant, and stubby, this unit can pretty much only be installed directly in front of the window. The manual says you should have 9 inches of clearance between the unit and the wall, which is impossible unless your window is exactly at hose height.In sum, if you have a horizontal sliding window (or maybe just a higher window), do yourself a favor and get the LG. I am not looking forward to the monumental task of packaging this back up to return.

CommentsContent: Update:No one has "reached out" to try to solve this great dilemma of this high tech device functioning like a toaster. I'm left with my original problem. Is this $700 a/c better than the $250 window unit it replaced? The old window unit had controls allowing me to switch to "low cool" which made it quieter. Did that make it cheaper to operate? I don't know. What I do know is the fan speed was constant, allowing me to not be distracted by the *constant* changing of speeds this unit does. Even making it operate on a certain percentage of fan speed still has it making unnecessary sounds as it tries to decide how much or little to run its compressor. It seems an insolvable problem for it, as it changes CONSTANTLY! Did I get a bad unit? I don't know. I have nothing to compare it to. No one has reached out and I haven't seen any kind of tech support that reaches a "real" person (emails apparently don't).Has my power bill gone down? Absolutely not. I'm still trying to justify to my wife the purchase of this unit. We're still using the same amount of power we were before. Even the old window unit had a setting to shut itself off when it reached the proper temp. This thing just runs and runs.I'm lowering my rating another two stars. Even though this thing has the ability to cool that's something of legend, if it can't shut itself off, that's just bad programming. It's a fantastic design with afterthought programming, or maybe budget cuts. Or...I just got a bad one. Guess we'll never know. Since—apparently—NO ONE CARES.----I don't understand the nuances behind its functioning. Even when the temp in the room is 2 or 3° below the setting, it's still running. IT RUNS CONSTANTLY! I've done everything I can to try to control it. It's ALWAYS running. Left on Auto fan, it changes the air speed constantly, regardless of the set temp or the temp in the room. The only way to get it to stop is to turn it off. WTF?!?This isn't what I got this for. It's constantly changing the compressor and fan speeds--constantly! It doesn't seem to know how to just leave good enough alone and shut DOWN!!! I have the app, the only way to have any level of control over it, but that does very little.The remote is completely useless. If you change the temp with the app, the remote is clueless and vice versa. If the a/c, the remote, and the app can't communicate with each other, what's the f'ing point?!?It's a solid product. It cools its a$$ off! It's a shame the software behind it is SO lacking. It's basically an on/off device because of incompetent programming. So much squandered potential....

CommentsDate: 评论于 2022年8月5日 在美国 🇺🇸 发布
CommentsContent:
So starting off, this Summer has been BRUTAL with EVERY single day in July/August over 100f and May/June being high 90 and low 100’s. The AC systems in our homes were struggling and racking up the bill with us spending often $9-11 a day to cool with both helping each other. We also have poor insulation which is something we’ve had to try and tackle ourselves.

In the end we got fed up of running the homes existing AC system because it was simply too expensive and opted to get a Window/Portable AC. The windows on our home are very flimsy and not at all suited for window units sadly and frankly we weren’t too keen on having to drill into things, worry about them falling out and having the hassle of having to bring them in every other season. So we opted to go for a portable.

Now there’s two different kinds of portable AC units. Single Hose and Dual Hose. Single hose units suck in air from the room which creates negative pressure in the room and pulling in hot air from either gaps/cracks in the doors/windows and blows all the hot air out the single hose. The single vent hose gets very hot - so between the negative pressure pulling in heat and the hot hose these single hose units have to try and fight those two things to keep the room cool which can REALLY lower their efficiency. Hence why you’ll see units advertise 14,000 BTU’s then in brackets have a lower BTU usually half of the first BTU rating. The second BTU number is the SAAC rating which basically takes into account the heat pulled into the room from the negative pressure and the hose and tells you how efficient it is. So units that advertise 14,000BTU typically use the power of a 14,000 BTU unit but are only really equivalent to a 7000 BTU unit with those other things taken into account.

Dual-hose units (like this one) pull air in from the outside eliminating much of the negative pressure issue (where heat is sucked in from cracks/windows/doors) hence why the secondary SAAC BTU rating is much higher. And in my experience the vent hose is actually much cooler.

This dual-hose design on the Midea/Toshiba is quite unique. They have decided to combine both hoses into one big wide unwieldy thing which sucks if you want to angle your portable AC to face it in a certain direction, but the benefit of it is that it goes vertically up from the back of the machine and bends up then down meaning you can shove it closer to and up-against the wall/window which you cant do on other units. Kudos to them. So it has its pros/cons. Pro: Being able to shove it against the wall / Con: not being able to angle it.

Now we first decided to buy the Toshiba version of this AC from Home Depot for our living room. It’s the exact same machine as this but in white. Midea and Toshiba are the same company. We set it up as soon as we received it and had it set up in minutes! I recommend cutting the foam seal tape down the middle so you have two strips and instead of sticking it on the window-sill, stick it around the window vent plate for the AC. That way you can remove the plate and shut the window in a jiffy if you decide to move the unit!

We set it up with the app straight away and I love all the features and control I have over the unit from the app. It’s awesome. Just to be clear the Toshiba app is what I use to control both my Midea and Toshiba unit (yes I bought a Midea after the Toshiba since I loved the unit so much!) The app allows you to remotely turn on the unit, set the temperature, the swing function, turn on/off the LED display, make schedules and more! I can’t go back to a different brand after having this (yes I tried to cheap out with my second portable - I’ll explain soon).

Anyhow we have a large openspace ground floor which merges into the upstairs hallway w/ high ceilings and despite this portable AC being rated for 550sqft it does an pretty good job of cooling the downstairs living area. Our master bedroom is downstairs and granted, that doesn’t get much cooling since its well out of the way but that’s fine. Since getting this portable AC we’ve been able to turn off our MAIN downstairs AC system from MORNING (when we get up and out the bedroom) till BED TIME when we go to bed. And this little guy keeps the downstairs living area VERY comfortable the entire day on its own during these 100-110f days in Texas. This has saved us a fortune in electricity.

Also this portable AC, not only does it have remote smartphone control, google home/alexa smarthome functionality BUT it also uses something called a smart variable inverter technology. So unlike other bog standard portable ACs which loudly turn on and run at full power/volume then shut off abrubptly when they meet the desired temp - then ramp up again when the temp creeps up. The Midea and Toshiba are able to gently ramp up and down the power depending on the situation. Other portable AC’s turn on and draw a full 1300W whereas the Midea/Toshiba can run and drop to as low as 50w when the fan is running, maintain temps at a low 300-500w or work a little harder and stay at 900w or if its really working hard ramp up to 1300w. This works brilliantly to save on the noise and power usage. It’s not running at all or nothing all the time. It’s smart, it can adjust the power and power draw to suit the conditions. This like I said helps conserve energy and keeps noise at a minimum. THAT BEING SAID, it would be nice if Midea/Toshiba added the ability in the app to allow us to force it to run at full power if we so wished rather than let it decide when to conserve power etc.

Overall, for our downstairs, this unit (at least the Toshiba we got) was WELL WORTH the investment.

NOW - Onto PART 2. Cooling the upstairs (specifically my home office) which I work in every day.

Despite the Toshiba version of this Midea doing an amazing job of cooling the downstairs. The upstairs and my office was like a damn oven. I came to the conclusion that if i wanted to get ANY work done in my office upstairs I had the choice of running the main upstairs AC which effectively couldn’t keep up and would run FULL blast the entire day costing us a fortune OR invest in another portable AC.

I decided to purchase another portable AC and instead of buying another Toshiba/Midea dual-hose unit I decided to cheap out and try the Black and Decker 14,000BTU(7000BTU SAAC) since it was well reviewed on Amazon despite it being a single hose unit with no smart features. Well…. BIG MISTAKE. As I said earlier in the review, the single hose was like a damn oven defeating the purpose of cooling the room if it has a hot burning heater of a hose behind it. I can’t talk about the negative pressure/leaking in hot air since I can’t measure that. But despite it being in a 100sqft office room and the unit was rated for 450sqft, it would run CONSTANTLY and STRUGGLE to keep the room at a comfortable temp. I asked myself “What’s the point of this thing” it cost me $500 after taxes and it was doing nothing. It also rumbled on and off and consumed max power at all times at some times going as high as 1800W almost tripping my breaker! Worst of all was I missed the app and smart controls I enjoyed on my downstairs Toshiba/Midea.
So… after a few days I bit the bullet and said screw this, filed a return on the Black and Decker and pulled the trigger on the Midea 14,000 (12,000btu saac) which essentially was just a couple of hundred dollars more with better efficiency and many more smart features/remote control.

I REALLY missed being able to turn the AC on in advance downstairs via the app and set schedules.

Well the Midea arrived, I liked the black as opposed to the white of the Toshiba but it’s essentially identical. The Midea app wasn’t compatible with my Z Fold 3 for some reason so I had a go at setting it up with the Toshiba app and to my surprise - the Midea AC works just fine with the Toshiba app as the Toshiba AC does! They are all essentially the same app with minor differences.

Well, weeks later I am THOROUGHLY impressed with the Midea as much as I am with my Toshiba downstairs. They are both on the same app so I can control both seperately using the one app which is nice.

I’ve not had any issue with the fan inside ripping itself apart or shaking the machine. It’s running perfectly. Just make sure its sitting on a good flat level surface :)

The Midea can cool my office down to the low 60’s if needed making it like a darn fridge. It’s awesome, I’ve had fun pushing it to its limits. It feels like magic on a 105f day, walking into my home office and it’s actually chilly cold lol.

I now have no need to use EITHER the main downstairs or upstairs AC systems LOL.

Anyhow, to round off my review I just want to share how ecstatic I am about this unit and have NO QUALMS about recommending it to others. Now as for the issues I have read, they could potentially be from dodgy delivery issues (from being bumped/knocked around or dropped during transport.) So I guess it really comes down to whether you get lucky and your unit moves through the delivery/courier system delicately or not. I saw some pictures where peoples boxes were all bashed in, dented and the rotating fan part was bashed into the unit. I suppose that could be why many of the people with issues have had such a bad experience - their unit was damaged in transport. But it seems I was lucky enough to receive my two units in good shape.

Now the Toshiba variant of this (in white) is actually selling for $649 on Home Depots website right now but they go in and out of stock on a regular basis and can be hard to buy (I guess they are popular) but if you can, why not save 50bucks. Plus I’d probably trust Home Depots delivery people more than Amazons for big fragile items like this. But if you get the Midea (providing the delivery/transport goes well) you’ll be just as happy.

My wife is now tempted to get one for her office upstairs and hell I wouldn’t mind getting one for our master bedroom downstairs too if budget permits one day. But I am VERY happy with my two units I have right now and I hope Toshiba/Midea keep supporting this unit because it is an absolute gem!

Pros:
- VERY ENERGY EFFICIENT
- Great for space (can tuck it closer to the wall/window) because of the hose design
- Much better SAAC BTU rating
- Decent noise
- LOTS of Smart Home functionality (APP and Google Home/Alexa support)

Cons:
- Can’t angle it left/right very much because of the dual-hose in one design
- Not as quiet as they advertise (but what can you expect when the condenser is inside the room with you)

JUST BUY IT ALREADY (and good luck with the delivery/shipping) :D

CommentsTitle: The drain design alone makes this a 1 star product
CommentsDate: 评论于 2022年8月1日 在美国 🇺🇸 发布
CommentsContent: The drain design alone makes this a 1 star product. Every portable air conditioner I have owned auto drains through the exhaust, but not this unit, it has a *manual* drain. Every 45 minutes the unit will stop cooling and display a P1 code meaning the drain needs to be emptied. The drain port is so low to the ground on the back of the unit you can barely get a dinner plate under it to catch the water coming out, and that is only with lifting the AC unit slightly for my plates, which keep in mind it is almost 80lbs. It is a very awkward exercise crawling on the floor, inevitably makes a mess, and when pulling the AC away from the wall to access the drain port the hose disconnects from the window and adds to the frustration. It comes with a drain hose to attach to the drain port to run to a drain source, and I tried using that hose to a bucket but it will not push the water up any elevation at all, so unless the bucket is somehow underneath the AC unit, it again just shuts off saying the drain needs to be emptied. I spent more time with towels to dry water off the hardwood floors from drain mishaps then I'd care to admit. Over an 8 hour period I'd need to do this 10+ times which is ridiculous. Aside from shutting off every 45 min, and requiring a painful manual drain procedure, the unit performs fantastic. Powerful, quiet, the auto rotating vents distribute air well. But the drain! Possibly not an issue in extremely dry climates. I'm returning this unit, it just isn't worth the hassle. The Whynter ARC-1230WNH is virtually the same unit featuring dual hose and inverter tech with the same BTU level, but it also properly auto drains through the exhaust and costs only $30 more, which is easily worth it.

CommentsDate: 评论于 2022年7月31日 在美国 🇺🇸 发布
CommentsContent: I have this same A/C in white.  It’s a terrific air conditioner.  When on the low setting, it really is very quiet.  However, when cranked up, it can get pretty loud, but it’s not as loud as the window units unless they have the inverter compressor as well.It really is an energy efficient A/C.  I’ve got mine hooked up to a watt meter with my electric rate and I’ve been running it straight for over a month (not on high) and I’ve only burned just under $55.00 in electricity.These A/C’s are good in that you don’t have a “box” sitting in your window.  Installation is very easy. Tip: put the adhesive insulation around the edging of the window plenum instead of on the window frame as noted in the instructions.  This way, you can remove it and switch to another window if you desire.  Of course, you’ll have to remove the pins that hold the length of the plenum in place if the window frames are different sizes, but it can be done.The trade off of the inverter as opposed to a normal compressor is that they don’t cool quite as well.  That’s not to say that these will not cool your room.  In a normal A/C, the compressor runs at a consistent speed the entire time and the air temp coming out is at it’s coldest whether on high or low.  So, you can set the window (non inverter) unit on low and the air comes out really cold.  However, your burning more electricity this way.The inverter compressor seems to be more tied to fan speed AND temperature.  In other words, when the fan is on the lowest, the compressor is not ramped up to it’s highest to have really cold air.  It’s cold, but not like on a normal compressor unit.  So, as you turn the temperature down, the fan will spool up accordingly. (Until the room cools down and then it will slow down.)  It’s strange, because the unit comes with 3 fan speeds, with the last being “auto”, but they all appear to have an “auto” mode from my experience.  This is what allows this particular unit though to be much more energy efficient.  If you like it really cold, then you’ll have to run this unit at the lowest temp with the highest fan setting.  It will be much louder, but still somewhat reasonable.  You may be better off with a traditional window unit (non inverter).  Again, it will slow down when the room finally gets to your desired temp setting.Many people complain about the condensate.  I live in the Houston area and have not had to drain it since I received it.  I have checked the drains in the rear and I did have about 3 or 4 ounces of water come out.  In order to test it completely, I hooked the included drain hose up to a 1 quart jar and let it run over night.  In the morning the jar was completely full.  The way the unit works (once the humidity level in the room has dropped due to usage) is that the unit uses the condensate to help cool the condenser.  It uses the condensate and evaporates it and exhausts it through the hose to help cool the unit.  It does work well since I have not had to drain the unit one time.Some people complain that they are always draining the unit due to the “error code” for a full condensate pan.  They must be in a room that is staying abnormally humid in order for this to occur.  Once the unit has dried the air out, it should not be a problems.  Remember, I’m in the Houston area and have not problems.In addition, a lot of people complain of the inconvenient drain plug at the very bottom of the unit.  I agree, that one is very inconvenient, being so close to the floor.  However, it’s the very top plug that the condensate initially drains from.  The bottom drain appears to be an overflow plug/reservoir to the top plug.  So if you’re in a humid environment, initially, check and drain from the top plug to begin with periodically, which is much easier to drain from.  Once the room has dropped to a reasonable humidity level, you should not have to drain it at all.  Again, I have not had to drain my unit one time.This Midea unit seems to be very popular, and rightfully so.  I was actually looking to buy a second one and could not find any.  I decided to try the Danby Inverter 3 in 1 unit.  Other than a cosmetically different air vent and remote control, in addition to only being the “3 in 1” unit, they are identical.  In fact, the Danby is manufactured by Midea.  The Danby unit works with the Midia phone app and the remote controls for each unit work on each unit as well.  The big difference between the two is that the Midea has the heat pump heater mode, where the Danby does not.  The Danby is generally cheaper too.So, if you are looking for the Midea and can do without the heater function, get the Danby since they are identical.Hopefully this helps someone with their decision making.

CommentsTitle: Unit fails when weather turns hot
CommentsDate: 评论于 2022年7月29日 在美国 🇺🇸 发布
CommentsContent: I bought this unit in February because I wanted to be prepared for the summer heat. I started using it in late May and it kept the house cool as I have another unit in the back room in between the two of them the house was nice. It's on its own dedicated circuit that's 20 amps so it shouldn't have a problem. The weather started getting about 95 to 100 this week and the machine would just pop the house circuit breaker it would not pop the breaker in the cord. The cord breaker is working because we can push test and it stops it but for some reason as soon as it gets hot outside it pops the house breaker. I tried plugging it into another outlet that wasn't on that circuit and it did the same thing. Once the weather cools down in the evening you can turn it on it'll run all night long if you want it to. Frustrating it's a lot of money can't return it because the return window is closed and it's not doing as good as the little unit I've had for 10 years.

CommentsDate: 评论于 2022年7月26日 在美国 🇺🇸 发布
CommentsContent: Ok, we were able to fix the rattling noise after about 1.5 hours of taking this beast apart. It's tricky but doable. I didn’t video it, but I will do my best to explain what we did.- Contact Amazon and get a refund. You’ll have to take a video of the rattling noise and send it to them. Once you’ve got your refund, you won’t be afraid to accidentally break this unit.- Take off the screen to the metal coils, and the hose.- Unscrew all the screws in the back of the unit. Don’t worry about the front. Note that the screws that are further in have a point in the end. The other screws have a flat end.- Turn the unit on its side and look at the bottom. On both sides, the case should bow out when you pull on it. There is an internal screw just inside the case. We took some pliers and dug it out, which was pretty easy. These screws don't seem to be integral to holding the unit together, so don’t worry about putting them back.- Turn the unit right side up. At the top of the unit, Take a flat head screwdriver and wedge it between the seam of the front and back casing. You’ll hear a snapping sound and that’s ok. The snaps holding the front and back are coming apart but not breaking. Continue to unsnap all the way down then repeat on both sides, using the screwdriver to help if needed (we needed it). The unit back should come off.Now the tricky part….- There is a plastic piece covering the fan and dividing the fan from the other part with metal coils. You’ll have to take this off. Unscrew the screws securing it, I think there are two.- Once the screws are removed, try and wiggle the plastic covering off. It’s tricky because there is a flimsy plastic piece holding it where the metal coils are while another part slides into place. Keep wiggling and fiddling with it. Once you get it, the sweet rush of this small victory will wash over you. You aren’t done yet, but take a moment to rejoice.- Once that plastic cover is off, you should see where the rattling noise is coming from. For us, the plastic piece above the fan is misaligned and part of it hangs down.- There are two screws that secure the casing around the fan. Removing them won’t take the casing off, but it will allow enough give that if you gently pull it apart, you can snap the misaligned plastic piece in place. One screw is located on the front of the fan casing, about 3 inches down. The other one is on the side.- Once those are off, you'll need two people for this part. One person needs to gently pull the plastic casing away and one person will maneuver the part hanging down above the fan into place.- The rattling noise should be fixed now. We were able to run it at that point to make sure.- Celebrate your full victory.I see a lot of other complaints about this unit. We’ve gotten it to work for the past hour, but who knows if it’ll encounter other issues. So far, it’s cooling our upstairs quickly and that’s all we can ask for right now.

CommentsTitle: Don't buy one with only 1 hose, it pulls air from outside which defeats it's purpose.
CommentsDate: 评论于 2022年7月25日 在美国 🇺🇸 发布
CommentsContent: This is nearly useless. It most a lot of air, and that air is indeed cooled. But the problem is that it's blowing air from inside, to outside. That means it needs to pull air somewhere else from outside to inside. So while it does work at cooling air, it doesn't actually cool the room off. This is in a small camper too, so only 168 sq feet. It should be overkill for this small space. The hose is horrible too, it's blowing hot air through it, and disipating that heat back into the room so you have to wrap it in insulation to keep that heat from escaping the blower vent host. If this had another hose for air intake it would definitely function better, then it would be able to cycle air from outside into the cooling unit, then blow the heated air back outside and cycle air from inside over the cooled coils for the cooling. It really has to be literally 3 feet away from me and pointed directly at me to have any beneficial cooling, the rest of the camper doesn't get any effect beccause of the air leaching from any crack/crevice that air can be pulled inside through. A window mounted unit was what I wanted but thought/hoped this would work better. Not in the least. Don't buy this unit, or any other that only has a vent for blowing the hot air outside.

CommentsDate: 评论于 2022年7月24日 在美国 🇺🇸 发布
CommentsContent: I purchased this air conditioner to cool down our bedroom at night so I don't need run central air and cool the whole house just to keep the bedroom temperature comfortable. The unit easily cuts trough the Wisconsin summer heat and humidity and cools not just the bedroom (approx. 150 sq. ft.) but also the hallway and parts of an adjacent office. Installation was not a big issue. All parts snap in easily, and I did not find the manual confusing at all. So, that is all good.What is not good is that at least in my case Midea overpromised on the noise level. This unit was not "extremely quiet" and is much louder than our refrigerator. I measured the noise and it was way beyond what is promised. I'd compare the noise level to a dryer (laundry) and found it impossible to sleep when the unit is on even on lower settings. Remember that they claim it is extremely quiet on the highest setting. I called Midea's customer service, which was responsive and easy to reach. Interestingly, they asked me about unusual noises (rattling, high-pitch, etc.) while I maintained that nothing seems to rattle or squeak , it is just very loud. Then, over the phone, the rep listened to the unit and said it does not sound right and I should send it back. They did not mention that I should get a replacement and that my unit might be unusually loud (that cannot be judged over the phone anyway). I sent it back and did not order a new unit because I am not confident that it would be quieter. Had they not made that comparison to the fridge, I wouldn't have bought it in the first place because I understand how loud the individual parts (condenser, fan, etc.) are. The reason why they have a highly-rated window unit is because they move these loud parts outside.Overall, great cooling, good customer service, questionable advertising for a loud AC.

CommentsTitle: It works OK, but the remote needs a lot of work
CommentsDate: 评论于 2022年7月24日 在美国 🇺🇸 发布
CommentsContent: The unit does cool a small room, but after awhile if the surrounding area isn't cool as well it draws in warm air from the rest of the house.  The exhaust tube needs to be insulated because it gets very hot and can defeat the purpose of the AC by heating the area around it.  The remote and related thermostat programming is way off.  I usually have to press the buttons twice (with new batteries) even if I'm right next to the unit. It rarely picks up a change to the thermostat setting and seems to turn on and off without reason. If it starts to get obviously warm, beyond the thermostat setting, the only way to get it to turn on is by turning the unit on and off.  So it requires resets often to work correctly.  Needs work, wouldn't recommend as there are better units out there.
